text: Indicates whether the material surface has 1 or 2 sides. Use 1 for closed objects and for thick transparent objects (made of the medium set as materialFront). Use 2 for non-closed objects (eg. tree leaf, sheet of paper) or for thin transparent objects (eg. glass window, helmet visor, bubble). When using 2 sides, not setting one of them is equivalent to setting the same material to both.
Material used on the front side (as defined by the geometric normal).
Material used on the back side (as defined by the geometric normal).

Connect a mask here to apply a cutout pattern to your object. This is useful for cutouts like creating leaves and other thin, complex shapes. It can also be used as opacity for gray values for semi-opaque results when seen directly by the camera.
Defines what the IOR of the exterior medium is (can be either the outside medium, eg. air or water, or in case of a layered material, the top layer medium, like plexiglass or varnish).
Enables/disables presence computation. Disabling it can speed up the render.
Enables/disables opacity computation. This should be turned on for transmissive materials (e.g. a dielectric). Disabling it can speed up the render.

Whether the renderer should cache presence (and opacity) or not. Caching these properties will lead to faster tracing, especially for shadow queries, but can lead to a less sharp result than uncached presence/opacity. (Note that checking either subsurface or interior computation will automatically disable presence/opacity caching.)
Enables/disables sub-surface scattering computation. This should be turned on for materials with SSS. Disabling it can speed up the render.

Enables/disables interior integrator computation. This should be turned on for materials with volumetric effects (e.g. a dielectric object with absorption). Disabling it can speed up the render. Note that enabling this when opacity computation is disabled will have no effect. Lastly, surface-level absorption (in a coating layer) does not require this to be enabled.
Can be plugged to a network returning a Color, to make sure it is evaluated.
Can be plugged to a network returning a Float, to make sure it is evaluated.
Can be plugged to a network returning an Integer, to make sure it is evaluated.
